title: Valentine Heart Message
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For my valentine.

Pull the heart handle to view the message, let go and it retracts back into the heart.

Requires 3/8" (9.525 mm) ribbon. In addition, my wife printed text on ink jet compatible heat transfer (iron on) paper to make the various messages, then ironed them onto the ribbon.

Video of prototype mechanism here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4G4Cmofq4Kk.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

See Notes

Notes:

Print "Back Enclosed.stl" and "Spring.stl" at 100% infill, the remaining parts at 20% infill.

I purchased 3/8" (9.525 mm) white ribbon and heat transfer paper for the messages, however, I wrote a couple of the ribbons by hand using an indelible ink pen.

I used cyanoacrylate glue to attach the ribbon to both "Handle.stl" and "Spool.stl". The location of the ribbon on "Spool.stl" was in the 7 o'clock position.

In order to not over torque "Spring.stl", and knowing that I wanted the ribbon to be approximately 100mm in length, I needed to design "Spool.stl" to have a circumference of 100mm. Here comes the math:

 Circumference = 2 * (pi) * radius,

which simplifies to

 Circumference = (pi) * Diameter.

Filling in the desired circumference

 100 = (pi) * Diameter
 Diameter = 100 / (pi)
 Diameter = 31.831

results in a diameter of 31.831. I rounded Diameter up to 32. Having a spool circumference of 100mm allows the ribbon to rotate the spool assembly 1 time during ribbon extension, which doesn't over torque the spring.

Finally, I designed "Back Enclosed.stl" and "Front.stl" to encapsulate the spool assembly.

title: Anet A8 right side brace/stiffener
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A right side stiffener to make the frame more rigid. It uses the present holes and slots in the acrylic. I use hex/Allen key screws to fixate the part, these are sunken in the part to not have the right x-axis mount contact the stiffener. Two existing screws need to be removed first before fitting the part.

BOM:
2 * Allen key M3 x 18 for far right screws
2 * Allen key M3 x 20 for replacing existing
2 * Allen key M3 x 30 for mounting to vertical part
Few washers

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Orange PLA @ 200 degC, 50degC aluminium heatbed with 3D-LAC (directly printed on heatbed with 215 degC/60degC), 6 mm brim (260% first layer extrusion [SLic3r]), no raft, no supports, 0.25 layer thickness, 25% infill (honeycomb) and 1 mm thick walls (4 layers).

Print scale 1.0.

Although this stiffens the right corner, the top of the printer still shows some flexibility. The reason for this is that the brace should preferably be attached higher (e.g. to the top plate). The printer bed is too small for printing such a part length I guess.

I think I will modify the printer in a later stage by acquiring an acrylic plate to cover the full height replacing the current second Z-axis motor back plate.

Hello,

Most holders are made to hold bare phone (without any case).

I glued holder and adapter together with strong solvent, but superglue is also good.

Happy printing!

title: Modular Robot Linear Module (ZaMoBot)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The modular robot is suitable for learning or teaching different configurations of robot manipulators. The complete modular robot Kit is composed of three main modules: Rotational module, Lineal Module, and under-actuated adapters.
The linear module complements the rotational module and can create millions of configurations by variating the geometry of the module itself, combining modules you can obtain manipulators from two DoF up to six DOF.
The design is meant to be assembly fast and repeatedly. This feature provides flexibility to try new configurations with very short preparation period. It is intended to use standard-size hobby servo which allows lower final cost.
Besides the screws for the base and servo, the module does not require any other additional mechanical equipment; the design comes with a fast and easy printable connector.
It is necessary to build the control for the servos as well as the electrical connection for the servos.
In the PDF there is a design for printed boards and ten-pin connectors that provide the capability of connecting the servos in serial connection. It can support up to 6 servos.
Print the base and attach it to a stable surface with four countersunk screws fix the first module with the printable clamp to the servo.

Tags: Robot, Robotic, Robotics, Manipulator, Control, Cool Robot, Robotic Arm, Educational Robot, Carlos Zarama

Printer:

M3D micro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print resolution of 0.2 or 0.15 might work with some sanding on the joints; for optimal results, It I recommend to print the parts with resolution 0.1mm or better.
The support material may interfere, remove it thoroughly.

Assemble the module and Serial connector

Follow the instructions to assemble the module. Print at least two clamps per module.
The module fits any digital or analog standard servo with 180 degrees of rotation; Higher rotation would damage the linear module, I calibrate the rack and gear of the module using this restriction.
The printable gear should be attached to the servo. I recommend using heavy duty, high torque and metallic gears for better performance. Nevertheless, I tried with the entry level Hitec® HS-311 and worked relatively well.
When creating any configuration, It is important to take in account mechanical interferences to avoid damage in the servos or modules.
The electrical serial connection for the modules is suggested for easier and faster configurations, but not required.
The PDF file contains the printed board's designs for install in the rotational module and linear module; the scale is 1:1 on a Letter 8.5"x11" paper size (not A4).

On going project

The design is a complete project for an educational modular robot made for my undergrad thesis in 2004 (Universidad De Los Andes, Bogota) using the concept of Prof Carlos F. Rodriguez and David Garzon. The designed has been updated for publication

The modular robot it´s meant to be fast and simple for the users. These parts are the fourth prototype version; the dimensions are proof to work with a resolution 0.1 or better.
I hope this will help to everyone interested in learn or teach manipulator controls. I would be pleased to post any picture or video of your projects.
Try the linear module for more configurations, and for more advanced control challenges try the underactuated module.
At this stage, I have no end effector designs yet.

description.text:
Version 2 is here! With This single quick release coupling one can attach almost anything to the Ultimakers Printhead. I'll soon release compatible toolheads for it (2012-04) Improvements (v2):

  • two templates included (raw & cylinder)

  • improved code quality (split in modules) capital lettered modules are meant to be printed or modified by the user

  • male part redesignd for a better print orientation that yields more stability. Still compatible to (v1)!

  • added option to close the slot and mount it by screwing not ziptieing for even more stability

  • slotdepth is now parametric (by taking two measures of your printhead; look for lxy & lxyspace in the malecoupling file)
    • Features (v1):

  • generic ... mount any tool you like

  • "quick" lock ... change the appandages on the fly

  • ziptie (or threads) only mount & thus non invasive

    ... the coupling >itself< is removable without disassemblage of the head

  • lightweight & almost no loss of printing space

    ... the coupling can stay on the printhead all the time

  • does not block the thing:

    "Bowden Clamp for Ultimaker (Heater End)" by owen

    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11864

  • one part design ... quick print

  • funny red cross shape fitting to a giant syringe appendage (pasteprinting)

Print with >=40% fill. When mounting it with zipties make sure they go BELOW the threads (see image) this way the left and rear endswitches will retain functionality. In the front and on the right only a few mm printspace will be lost. Choose toolhead: drill: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20891 syringe: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21302 .... Or create your own: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21297 Heck you could even modify a coat hook to be mountable ;) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16920

author: wilcovandepol

title: Modular Robot Under-Actuated Modules (ZaMoBot)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The modular robot is suitable for learning or teaching different configurations of robot manipulators. The complete modular robot Kit is composed of three main modules: Rotational module, Linear Module, and under-actuated adapters.
The under-actuated adapter modules work along with the rotational module and can create millions of configurations by variating the geometry of the module itself, combining modules you can obtain manipulators from two DoF up to six DOF.

  • The primary adapter (adapter for the rotational module) provides a reliable connection with the servo and housing for an encoder for closed loop control.
  • The free axis assembly is designed to use inexpensive standard skate roller ball bearings. Ther is no power to this element and the challenge is to balance the element using the powered axis. This part also includes housing for encoders to provide position and velocity to the controller.
    -The last two elements -Momentum Wheel and Weight Holder- provide means to vary the inertia to the system. The wheel can be filled with plaster, and the elongated element can be filled with metal coins or plaster in different positions. This feature allows the system to change the dynamic conditions of the whole system and therefore the control should be modified accordingly.

The design is meant to be assembly fast and repeatedly. This feature provides flexibility to try new configurations with very short preparation period. It is intended to use standard-size hobby servo which allows lower final cost.
Besides the screws for the base and servo, the module does not require any other additional mechanical equipment; the design comes with a fast and easy printable connector.

Tags: Robot, Robotic, Robotics, Manipulator, Control, Cool Robot, Robotic Arm, Educational Robot

Printer:

M3D micro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print resolution of 0.2 or 0.15 might work with some sanding on the joints; for optimal results, It I recommend to print the parts with resolution 0.1mm or better.
The support material may interfere, remove it thoroughly.

Assembly and serial connection

Start with the rotational module and install the adapter.
The user should make an adaptation for the encoder. The part provides the ball bearing housing and small axis tip. (TI did not have an encoder standard to use in this case)
Follow the instructions to assemble the module.

Attached the free axis element and use two standard roller skating ball bearings to attach the free axis to the part body.

Attach the inertial element and vary the weights. The control system should allow sensors and closed loop controls.

A good starting point for use this system is this publication.
Modular System for Teaching Kinematics Control of Robot Manipulators
Carlos F. Rodriguez and Carlos A. Zarama

http://proceedings.asmedigitalcollection.asme.org/proceeding.aspx?articleid=1580895

Educational

The design is a complete project for an educational modular robot made for my undergrad thesis in 2004 (Universidad De Los Andes, Bogota) using the concept of Prof Carlos F. Rodriguez and David Garzon. The designed has been updated for publication

The modular robot it´s meant to be fast and simple for the users. These parts are the fourth prototype version; the dimensions are proof to work with a resolution 0.1 or better.
I hope this will help to everyone interested in learn or teach manipulator controls. I would be pleased to post any picture or video of your projects.
Try the linear module for more configurations, and for more advanced control challenges try the underactuated module.
At this stage, I have no end effector designs yet.
If you like it, consider leaving a tip, with your support I will make more developments.

description.text: A mash up I made of various animal models. Meant to be used as a monster board piece in a board game. This one titled the 'Chrocodile', is a mash-up of the Chimera and a crocodile, with a Louisiana bayou aesthetic.

I made This Wind Turbine project to learn solid works better, I then 3D printed it out on my Untimaker 2+. All parts printed out perfectly and went together and looks very fluid. I then milled out the swivel shaft and main shaft but they could be 3D printed if you preferred. There is space in the back to put a small motor if you wish for It to spin. I have given solid works files along with STL files so it can be printed even if you don't have solid works or if you want to change anything.

description.text: I found of my Anet A8 printer that the nozzle would constantly catch the part of the already laid down parts and lift them and end up ruining the complete print. I watch and found the part of the print was being caught was the part where it raises up for the shaped end with the indentations. So used Tinkercad to realign the chain links so that the indentation is now pointing outwards and hence the nozzle no longer catches them.

This door was designed to cover water valves located in a wall in a garage. The door will accept a lock such as Fasmov Drawer & Cabinet Lock Cam locks with 1-1/4" Cylinder available on Amazon. I cut a coat hanger (1.9mm diameter wire) to make the hinge wire.

Frame has 4 screw holes for mounting.

It was printed using Atomic Filament Gun Metal Gray PLA at 210C/Bed at 60C. Printed with frame face on the bed with support bed only.

Door opening is 204mmx164mm.

Filament connector, nozzle mit 0,3mm auf 1,75mm aufbohren.

auf beiden seiten das filament rein und lässt 3-5mm am nozzle rausschauen. ich nehme so einen kleinen bunzenbrenner weil man den hinstellen kann, und halte die zwei spitzen kurz drüber so das die schmelzen, führe dann die zwei halter zusammen und drehen. abkühlen lassen und tadaaa verbunden. die zwei wulsten die an der verbindung entstehen kann man einfach abpopeln. ich hab zwei nozzle genommen und das loch auf 1,75mm aufbebohrt dann mit ratsche und nuss in die halter gedreht. paar mal üben dann geht das gut. viel spaß ;-)

I printed the 7mm version of the source and found that the Syma D63 is even tinier than most quadcopters. With that in mind I recreated the design from scratch to fit smaller rotors, 7mm motors and also has the particular flight controller mount that fits the Syma board.
The ducts are a close fit for the 37.5mm propellers and curved to a NACA 0020 airfoil shape which should be more efficient. (at least in theory)

You will need a soldering iron to disconnect the motor wires in order to extract them from the original frame without breaking it. They can be soldered back on once removed from the frame.

I printed mine in T-Glase Orion Blue. This plastic will take most bounces although it might crack on a super hard impact. I've tried to make most of the external structures to be light and thin so they are a bit flexible.

title: Anet A8 e3d v6 Bowden Print Carriage Redux

description.text:
This is a combine work project between myself and Dan Rogers. The purpose was to create a print head mount that allows the user some customization to their exact/ or wanted setup This is for a Bowden setup. There are 4 variations of the mount: 

           -Sensor with cooling fan
           -Sensor without cooling fan
           -No sensor with cooling fan
           -No sensor without cooling fan

Many of the parts are interchangeable if you wish to make changes down the road as you upgrade/ change you own setup.

There is some required materials for assembly and they are as follows:

      - M3 Hex nut: 8 pieces
      - M3 Screw 25mm length: 7 pieces
      - M3 screw 20mm length: 1 piece
      - The 12 existing screws used to mount the existing carriage to the axis

You can use standard screws or socket head screws

Printing

You will want to use some supports when printing the PRINT CARRIAGE PLATE and the HEAD LOCK. DONT use supports when printing the cooling fan duct.

See the images for the recommended part orientations when printing.

Assembly

Prior to assembly, you will want to press fit four (4) M3 hex nuts into the carriage plate, two (2) into the head lock ( the two slots along the top, confirm they align with the screw holes) and 1 into the fan mount (again confirm they align with the screw hole)

Step 1: Attach the belt holder to the back of the carriage plate ( be sure the opening is facing down) Use four (4) M3x25 screws to do this.

Step 2: Attach the print carriage to the bearings on the X axis. Using the existing 12 screws. It is recommended using the cross tightening method. Then once all screws are in tighten them all down

Step 3: Place the e3d v6 into its opening on the print carriage and attach the desired head lock (fan or no fan). Using two (2) M3x25mm screws This will be a snug fit

At this point if you are not using a sensor or the fan your carriage is completed

Step 4: Attach the turbo fan (5015- radial cooling fan) using one (1) M3x20 screw on the upper most hole and one (1) m3x25 screw on the lower hole

Step 5: Attach the cooling ring to the turbo fan

At this point if you are not using a leveling sensor your carriage is completed

Step 6: Attach your leveling sensor (proximity or inductive) to the mount using the included hardware with the purchase of one.

FINAL STEP FOR EVERY VARIATION
Secure your wires with a zip tie through the slots on the side of the print carriage. This is HIGHLY recommended as stress relief.

Sensor
This thing is designed for an 18mm sensor or a 12mm sensor. So when choosing your print carriage, be sure to select WHICH file you want.

Sensor offsets
With this design the offset of the center of the sensor to the center of the nozzle is: 

           **-28.873mm**

Please post make pictures if you print and use this print head!

EDIT 2/15/2016

The Co-designer Dan Rogers has released a new cooling fan duct that works along with this print head at the following link. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2086437 . The goal was to create a lower profile cooling duct.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

60-70%

Notes:

For details on the supports please read through the description

CHAOS EMRE

I'm a really big fan of Youtube myself and I just like the idea of custom Keyrings, so i started to design this... Halfway through I thought "I just have to make this two colored other wise it just doesn't look good!"... so I came up with this design:

The white part easily slides into the gap in the red part which makes the logo look super cool. The one end of the white part locks it in place on the one side and when you put keys on the ring it's impossible that the two parts seperate.

For the fully assembled Keyring you need to download both STL files and print the body in red and the other part white.

As I am pretty new to this website and 3D-Printing in general I would appreciate any kind of feedback!

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Settings aren't that import to my knowledge although the gap is about 1,5cm big and the printer has to print that whole line in the air.
It worked just fine on my printer without support but if it doesn't let me know because you might have to enable support or slightly adjust other settings.

Although the white ring is only 1mm thick it's solid as a rock. At first I was afraid that it could break easily but after a couple of tests it turns out that the metal ring (it's a small metal ring) is more likely to break than the PLA.

Designed with 123D Design and took about 1 hour for the finished model. I tried to make the shape of the logo as exact as possible and i think it came out fine.
I also left the 123dx folder as a download because you might want to make the white part a bit thicker so it fits thighter but you have to test that with your printer.
You can also edit the ring to make it fit whatever keys you want!

It's Super Meat Boy! I love this game and I love the character as well. My wife was the one who created this model in ZBrush Core. She started with cylinders for the body and limbs and just started sculpting to get the shape, and then added in the details of the face.

After that I imported it into Meshmixer. I used the plane cut tool to cut off a little extra on the feet so he would stand on his own. Then I sent it over to my printer and printed it out (settings below).

Finally my wife painted it up using a combination of spray paint and paintbrush techniques. I describe it in more detail in the video and I've uploaded the full painting video as well, if you're interested in that.

title: Box Shelf Clever Attached to Wire Rope

description.text:
For storing all of my tinkering stuff i created this box shelf.

https://youtu.be/WbqlUxAku0U
https://youtu.be/DfYb214mytE
(The first video is a short version of the second one witch has German explanations to this project.)

Every box is either dedicated to a specific tinkering project or stores general tinker material. The idea is to have thous boxes next to each other witch contains related content.

Wile designing this shelf, my goal was, to create an unique example of using the belt friction for holding an item on a wire rope.

The *.stl files witch are provided fits with an box with an depth of 10.8cm. But you can also design your own side parts witch fits to your box.

You will need for this project:

3d-printer pilament and 3d-printer
Wire rope Ø2mm
Wood stick Ø6mm
Wood stick Ø8mm
Screws and Dowels
Cardboard box
and some basic tools

Notes:

If you use a extrusion with of 0.3mm and 3 perimeter, you will get a part with 100% infill. Because the wall thickness is 1.8mm.

description.text: This is the final iteration of my first 3D printed object. The goal was to create a pocket sized cord management system so my iPhone charger would not get tangled in my backpack or pocket. I personalized it with my initials.

This design is a 3D note holder. This tool is meant to be placed on any kind of work desk used for writing notes. In this age of digital computing and information sharing, I still find it useful to take notes on physical pieces of paper. This desk tool is meant to organize notebooks, paper, pens, pencils, and index cards, keeping them out of the way of your work area. At the same time, this design keeps those things close at hand for whenever you need to take hard copy notes.

The front "wall" area of the design is meant to hold pens or pencils. Pens and pencils will protrude from the front of the design and be held in place by the holes in and behind the wall. The raised portion in the middle has two slots for index cards. Users can store index cards here for easy access. Finally, the rear portion of the design is meant to house 8.5x11in sheets of paper. This will most likely take the form of a notebook, or some other ruled sheet of paper, though any piece of paper with those measurements could be theoretically stored here as well.

Note: I would not recommend this design for printing. It is my first stab at 3D design and I'm sure the proportions/measurements are off.

title: Upgrade extruder fan bracket anet A6
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I have noticed that the front fan of the A6 ring basically does nothing, and hinders when changing the filament. So I made this piece that solves those two things, already cooling the top of the extruder and does not bother when we have to change the filament. I have been testing with ABS and PLA and have not noticed that it has worsened the print quality with this modification.
To fasten the fan to the piece I have used 4 lag screws for wood.

Me he fijado que el ventilador frontal de la anet A6 básicamente no hace nada y ademas estorba cuando queremos cambiar el filamento, así que he diseñado este nuevo soporte para el ventilador que resuelve esos dos problemas: enfría la parte superior del extrusor y no molesta a la hora de cambiar el filamento. He estado probando con ABS y PLA y no he notado que haya empeorado la calidad de impresión con esta modificación.
Para sujetar el ventilador a la pieza he usado 4 tirafondos para madera.

The backstory:
So I got a hold of some Nylon filament, and it printed surprisingly well on my Ultimaker2+. Happily I forgot to store the spool properly, and after a day of damp weather the nylon had absorbed so much moisture, that printing was reduced to a lot of fizzing and almost no layer adhesion. Crap.

As any maker knows: When there's a problem, CAD'll solve it. I gathered a few things I had lying around and drew up a few parts in fusion360. It took a couple of iterations to get things right, and there's still a few minor tweaks that could be made, but for my setup it's pretty much what I need and I'm loving the setup so far and thought I'd share it with the community.

TL:DR; Moisture gets into your filaments and degrades print quality and absolutely ruins your day. This'll help you fix that.

Bill of materials:

  • Carbon rod 8mm diameter
  • Bowden tube that fits your filament size
  • 4 couplings, that fit the bowden tube
  • Some hotglue or M3 screws to secure the brackets holding the rods
  • A sponge for the filter
  • A airtight container, that'll fit your spool size. I had one that wasn't airtight, but made it airtight by adding sealing strip.

Again I hope some will find this useful, give me a like if you like it and post a picture of your make, should you decide to make one show it off!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is my desktop 10W Led spot. It uses a 10W led, a 40 x 40mm fan and a step down controller.

The LED panel is friction fit and requires no bolts or screws.

This led can be run from 12v to 24vdc. I recommend 12vdc.
I set the voltage on the regulator while measuring the amps drawn between the led and the regulator to max 900 ma.

The heatsink I used is 36.2 x 30.2 x 15.2mm that I had lying around.
The step down controller can be found on ebay, search for : LM2596s DC-DC Buck Converter Power Supply Step Down Module Voltage Regulator
The power switch is a Rocker 6A 230VAC SPST Locking with a body size of 17 x 12 x 13mm.
The 10w led can be found on ebay by searching for 10w high power led.

The wire going to your supply is inside the mount.

The stand uses a M6 x 20 bolt and 6mm nut.
To attach the mount to the led box use 4 of M3 x 6 self tappers. (M3 x 8 Max)

The holes for the mount in the box is 2.6mm so you can also try a M3 x 6 (or 8) caphead bolt, it should cut threads in the casing holes.

title: Beekeeper's car propolis bottle holder

description.text:
If you are a beekeeper who keeps propolis bottles in your car in the cheap plastic bag, and they overturn during breaking, and one of the bottles leaks and makes a mess, you will regret you did not 3D print this bottle holder now!

I use 7 bottle version, but if you want to use it in your car door storage compartment, you might want to go with 4 bottle model. Base of this holder is rough enough to keep it location firmly in the back of my car, even without strapping it in any way.

Holes are 29mm in diameter and the entire thing is 30mm high. If you want to make a lid, just use the same model and scale it in the proper direction.

PS: yes, you can use it also as lipstick holder, even though I did not test it that way.

title: CYNO01 Arduino Robot walker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cyno01 est mon premier essais en conception et impression 3D.
Je me suis inspiré de µBipedino http://robotshop.com/letsmakerobots/node/30394,
et des déviations ZOWI, TITO, BOB...

Le robot se déplace avec une bonne autonomie, il reconnaît les obstacles et
cherche une issue, avance, recule, tourne droite ou gauche, danse, salut...
La CAO et le code Arduino sont disponibles sous les zip "cyno1-FREECAD" &
"cyno1-v1-2-arduino"

Cyno moves with good autonomy. In the last design, I used 6AA batteries.
The robot recognizes the obstacles and seeks an exit, walk forward & back,
turns right & left, dance...
CAD and Arduino code are available under zip called "cyno1-FREECAD" &
"cyno1-v1-2-arduino"
On the video, you can see an exemple of his possibilities. After his initialisation,
he walk, dance, look to the right & left and then move for safe ^^

La nomenclature :
4 x Servo S3117 TOPMODEL
1 x 700092 Inter CONRAD
1 x 624691 Contact pression CONRAD
1 x 615587 COUPLEUR 6 R6 CONRAD
6 x AA 2300mAh
1 x ARDUINO UNO
1 x Régulateur 7806
1 x CAPTEUR IF SHARP GP2Y0A21YK0F

Le montage se fait sans aucune vis, simplement des emboitements ou clipsages.
Les disques des servos se fixent sur les jambes simplement à l'aide d'agrafes.

Sur la vidéo, dans l'ordre on le voit dire bonjour, danser, voir un obstacle,
regarder à droite puis à gauche, et partir vers un endroit dégagé :p

title: Change Filament At Z Cura Plugin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATED v3.2: If your plugin doesn't display a version, it's v1.0. The latest version is v3.2. Please keep coming back for updates or click the Watch button.

"ChangeAtHeight.py" is the Cura 2 and Cura 3 version of the plugin. "changeAtZ.py" is the legacy Cura 15 and Cura 16 version.

DESCRIPTION: With a single extruder printer, sometimes you want to switch filaments during a print to make something a little different or just pause at a particular layer to insert something.

The plugin, once installed into your Cura plugins folder, shows up as the "Change filament at height" plugin.

Usage (with default settings):

Cura:

  1. Switch to the layer view and determine the layer which you want to pause at. It will pause at the beginning of the layer that you choose.
  2. From Cura's main menu, choose Extensions->Post Processing->Modify G-Ccode
  3. Click the "Add a script" button
  4. Choose "Change filament at height"
  5. Enter the desired layer in the "Pause at layer" box
  6. Click the "Close" button
  7. For additional pauses, simply repeat
  8. Save the G-Code file to an SD card

The "Cool extruder on pause" feature is not compatible with multiple extruders. It won't know which extruder to heat back up or which temp to use. So, disable that feature if you're using multiple extruders.

Printer:

  1. Print the file from the SD card
  2. The printer will pause at the designated layer, turn off the extruder heat to avoid burning the filament in the nozzle, then beep to get your attention
  3. On the printer's control box, under the SD Card menu, choose "Continue Print". The printer will lock the stepper motors then beep. If you are inserting items, now's the time to do it.
  4. When you are ready to change filament or resume, choose "Continue Print" again, and your extruder will start heating back up to temperature. Once the extruder is at temperature, the printer will lock the stepper motors then beep again. If you are changing filament, now's the time to do it.
  5. Once you've changed the filament or are ready to resume, choose "Continue Print". The plugin will immediately prime the nozzle, then beep again.
  6. Wipe the nozzle then choose "Continue Print" the final time to resume the print.

In summary, here's the sequence each time you "Continue Print":

  1. Lock stepper motors (insert items)
  2. Heat up extruder (wait for it...) then lock stepper motors (change filament)
  3. Prime nozzle (wipe)
  4. Resume print

See the photo of my dragon print for an example of how well it works. The print was tiny. The photo shows the print sitting on my computer keyboard.

Here's the project that I actually designed this plugin for:
Personalized Glowing Valentines for Kids Remake
Here are my latest change filament projects:
Magnetic Construction Toys
No Soliciting Girl Scout Cookies Sign

IMPORTANT: If you set a value for "Move print head Z", it will attempt to raise the nozzle by that amount from the current z height, up to the max your printer allows. Leave the "Move print head Z" parameter at 5mm to move the head up 5mm from the print before parking. Setting it to 0 still raises it a minimum of 1 layer. If the current z height plus the value that you enter is less than 25mm, it will raise up to a minimum of 25mm so that you have room to work under the nozzle. If you put in a large value, you could possibly ruin your print or damage your cables (if your printer configuration reports a larger max Z than it actually allows because of cables, extruder height, etc.). Avoid using X and Y of 0 and 0 because your printer may hit your limit switches, causing it to lose a step or two. For my printer, Park X and Y of 10 and 10 puts it in the front left. 190 and 190 puts it in the back right (depends on your bed size). The plugin only pauses if you are printing from an SD card or Octoprint.

Cura 2 or 3 INSTALLATION: To install, simply close down Cura, drop the ChangeAtHeight.py file into the Cura PostProcessingPlugin plugins folder, then restart Cura. My plugins folder, using the default path, was at: C:\Program Files\Cura 2.x\plugins\PostProcessingPlugin\scripts for Cura 2.x and C:\Program Files\Ultimaker Cura 3.x\plugins\PostProcessingPlugin\scripts for Cura 3.x.

Verified Printers:

  • Wanhao Duplicator i3
  • Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus
  • Monoprice Maker Select
  • Monoprice Maker Select Plus
  • Balco 3D Printer
  • Balco 3D Printer Touch
  • Prusa i3
  • Anet A8

Possible Printers:

  • Malyan M150
  • Cocoon Create
  • Tevo Tarantula I3
  • Any Repetier firmware printer

Does NOT work with these printers

  • Monoprice Maker Select Ultimate
  • Ultimaker
  • Ultimaker 2
  • Printrbot simple metal
  • Anycubic i3 Mega

If you have a compatible printer and this plugin works for you, please let me know so that I can add it. My Monoprice Maker Select uses the Repetier firmware. I'm guessing that this plugin will work with any Repetier firmware based printer. The Marlin firmware seems to support all of the same commands, so it should also work with any Marlin firmware based printer. Thank you.

Troubleshooting:

  • If you are not printing from an SD card, this plugin will not work! It will not pause! You must print from an SD card (or with Octoprint)
  • Some versions of Cura have a bug and don't automatically reslice when you add the post processing plugin to your project. You may need to force Cura to reslice. This can easily be done by, e.g. turning retraction on and off.
  • If you are printing a large model, you may wish to ensure that the pause is present in your G-Code file before you start the print. Simply open up the G-Code file in a text editor and search for the text "CUSTOM" to find the G-Code that was added by the plugin.
  • You will need to install the plugin for each version of Cura that you install onto your computer.
  • The plugin pauses at the beginning of the layer that you choose.

Version 3.2 Changes:

  • Fixed bug where the plugin wasn't looking for resets to the extruder position in the middle of the print (why, Cura?), so it was setting the extruder value to the wrong value when resuming print (Thank you, papavomsee)

Version 3.1 Changes:

  • Fixed bug where the plugin wasn't finding extruder temperatures before the first layer, so it wasn't resuming at the correct extruder temperature for some users. (Thank you, poswald, eyal3388, and alexanderfreddy25)

Version 3.0 Changes:

  • Added option to choose the layer by layer number or by height (Now defaults to "Layer" because it's so much easier. Just use the layer preview. No more maths!) (Thanks for the motivation, RustyCrackleford)
  • Added option to cool the extruder on pause (On by default) (Thanks for the suggestion, RustyCrackleford)
  • Added option to turn off the beep

Version 2.0 Changes:

  • Added retraction parameters for greater control and especially for those with Bowden tube printers
  • Added retraction distance parameter
  • Added extrusion distance parameter
  • Added prime distance parameter
  • Lowered default retraction (and extrusion) from 7mm to 5mm

Version 1.3 Changes:

  • Added retraction immediately after the cleanup stage to mitigate any oozing while it moves to the resume location

Version 1.2 Changes:

  • Reset the extruder position in case the last movement was a retraction, which avoids extruding extra material when it restarts
  • Fixed to work with multiple filament changes (at different heights) in the same project

Version 1.1 Changes:

  • Renamed the "Head park Z" parameter to "Head move Z" to more accurately portray what the parameter does
  • Ensure that we always raise at least 1 layer
  • Ignore negative values for all parameters (defaults to 0)
  • Changed default "Head move Z" value from 0 to 5

Cura 15 and 16 are no longer supported and will not receive updates for this plugin.

Legacy Cura 15/16 Change Height at Z v2.0 Plugin
Cura 15 INSTALLATION: To see the plugins, you'll need to switch from "Quick print" to "Full settings" in the Expert menu. To install, simply close down Cura, drop the changeAtZ.py file into the Cura plugins folder, then restart Cura. My plugins folder, using the default path, was at: C:\Program Files (x86)\monoprice\IIIP\IIIP15.01\plugins

The plugins folder for the downloaded version of Cura 15 was at: C:\Program Files (x86)\Cura_15.04.6\plugins

Interestingly, the plugins folder is not IN the Cura folder, but next to it.

(Wanhao) Cura 16 INSTALLATION: To see the plugins, you'll need to switch from "Quick print" to "Full settings" in the Expert menu. To install, simply close down Cura, drop the changeAtZ.py file into the Cura plugins folder, then restart Cura. My plugins folder, using the default path, was at:C:\Program Files (x86)\WANHAO 3D PRINTER\WANHAO-16.01\wanhao-cura\plugins

Printer:

Maker Select 13860

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.10mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed the dragon at 0.1mm resolution. The background layer is 0.3mm thick, and my first layer is set to 0.2mm, so I set the plugin "Change Filament at Height" to 0.4mm, which ended up being the third layer. This allowed me to change the filament from clear for the background to orange for the dragon.silhouette. Alternatively, I can just choose Layer 3.

comments.text: I'm guessing that you have your Printing Temperature set to 0 in Cura and are preheating the printer at the control box. You need to use the Printing Temperature in Cura because that is the temperature that the plugin uses. Since you have it set to 0, that is what the plugin sets the temp to. If you don't think that's the case, please include the entire GCode, or at least the lines where it sets the temp in the GCode (the M104 and M109 lines). Thank you.

comments.text:
I had to look at GCode to see what it is doing. It appears to be by design, but is repeating itself:
;LAYER:2
;TYPE:CUSTOM
;added code by post processing
;script: ChangeAtHeight.py
;current z: 0.500000
M83 ;Set extruder to relative mode
G1 E-5.000000 F2400 ;Retract
G1 X10.000000 Y10.000000 Z25.000000 F3000 ;Move head away
M104 S0 ;Turn off extruder heat
M117 Press Continue...
M300 ;Beep
M25 ;Pause
G91 ;Set to relative position mode
G1 X-0.1 Y-0.1 Z-0.1 ; Lock motors
G1 X0.1 Y0.1 Z0.1 ; Lock motors
G90 ;Set back to absolute position mode
M117 Press Continue...
M300 ;Beep
M25 ;Pause
G91 ;Set to relative position mode
G1 X-0.1 Y-0.1 Z-0.1 ; Lock motors
G1 X0.1 Y0.1 Z0.1 ; Lock motors
G90 ;Set back to absolute position mode
M117 Heating extruder...
M109 S190.000000 ;Heat extruder back up for filament change (wait)
M117 Press Continue...
M300 ;Beep
M25 ;Pause
G91 ;Set to relative position mode
G1 X-0.1 Y-0.1 Z-0.1 ; Lock motors
G1 X0.1 Y0.1 Z0.1 ; Lock motors
G90 ;Set back to absolute position mode
;Prime nozzle
G1 E6.000000 F6000
G1 E-5.000000 F6000
M117 Press Continue...
M300 ;Beep
M25 ;Pause
G1 E-5.000000 F2400 ;Retract
G1 X79.985000 Y106.099000 Z0.500000 F3000 ;Move to next layer position
G1 E5.000000 F2400 ;Extrude
M82 ;Set extruder back to absolute mode
G92 E23.710640 ;Set the extrude value to the previous (before last retraction)
M117 Printing...

comments.text: It stays locked for me. The script doesn't disengage the motors. However, you might have a "Stepper Inactive" set in your firmware. My firmware defaulted to 360. That's the number of seconds that the motors automatically disable after being idle. So, if I take more than 6 minutes to switch the filaments, the steppers will automatically disable. You can increase this time in your firmware (available from the Configuration menu on the controller on my printer), or stay attentive and change the filament quickly.

comments.text: This worked perfectly for me. On my Monoprice Maker Select, it parks the head at the home position well above the bed.  I then MANUALLY pull the filament and load MANUALLY the new filament.  On loading, give the new filament a little time to reach melting temperature, then hold the clamp on the extruder head and advance the filament until the color change is complete.  Hit "continue" and it resumes where it left off.  DO NOT leave the "print" screen, don't attempt to use the unload and load filament functions under the tools menu. REMAIN in PRINT the entire time. I'm making replacement draw knobs for a pipe organ and wanted a white face label with black background. Works perfectly! Salamat po.

description.text:
This is work in progress, many things can change.

Some time ago I was wondering about space efficient way of growing herbs and vegetables.
I have searched something about it, and I found - window farm. After some thinking I designed it, and here it is! My window farm is made to be modular, and easy to accommodate to your needs. You can choose between vary of pot sizes, connectors and other stuff. Your window farm is only limited with your imagination.

Everything is optimized for 200mmx200mm bed and fast printing.

For smaller systems you can use airlift, for bigger pneumatic ejector pump.
Pots have 6mm hole going through so you can glue there pipe for airlift and increased strength. You can use rod instead, and grow plants with long stems. Pot connectors have holes too, so you can use one water pipe for all columns. You can also set number of water drains too.

Feel free to comment and remix.

Big pots are printed with vase mode. If big pot leaks on layer change, add additional filament on restart.

Pot

Glue basket (round thing under pot) to pot, and add 200mm long tube if you want (it should stick out at the bottom for 30mm). Connector is designed for push-fit

Finished pot with airlift tube Big pot

For big pot seal it with glue if it leaks and make holes in middle column to determine water height.
To connect put tube between big pots, and push big pot connector from top

Connected big pots Water drain

Water drain is very customizable - you can make vary of setups. For one column use end_single. For 2 or 3 columns use 2 end_single and end_double at the middle. For 4+ columns use end_single at sides, end_multi_side for middle columns, and end_multi_middle.

In other words:

  • end_single - 1x6mm
  • end_double 2x6mm, 1x8mm
  • end_multi_side 1x6mm, 1x8mm
  • end_multi_middle 3x8mm

To fit airlift tube inside you may need some sanding and glueing.

To end WIP phase I will design following things:

  • pneumatic ejector pump for better efficiency and water flow
  • reinforcement for big pot
  • big pot siphon (airlift tube and no tube version)
  • water splitter

author: katiep

title: Standing Baby Groot (Reworked to Print w No Raft)

description.text:
Hi,

I have uploaded a Simplify "Factory" file with the supports, if you can load it, Yay!

I went in and reworked the feet to allow you to print without a raft and have perfectly flat feet. You will still have to print with support for the hands. Print as high rez and as large as you can. I print in MEDIUM on my MakerGear M2 and it looks great, I never even have to do Hi-Rez.
BUT...READ THIS FIRST::: A LOT of people have written to me saying "I printed it with no supports like you said and the hands are all spaghetti!"...ok folks...allow me to explain some tech so that you can just print this and not waste time and filament. The title says "reworked to print with NO RAFT", not No Supports, see the difference? This is so that you can print directly to the glass or tape and the feet will be perfectly flat to stand on your table...this doesnt mean that you dont have to ADD SUPPORTS MANUALLY TO THE HANDS. (I may try to upload one with all the supports in place so you can just print it).
A "RAFT" in 3D Printing terms is a set of layers that is laid down before the print starts, to give the thing something to stand on and for other supports to adhere to if you are having trouble making it adhere to the glass or dont want to for some reason.
What you need to do BEFORE YOU PRINT is to go in and manually define the supports for the hands, or automagically if your software does this. I use Simplify 3D and I just manually place extra supports at the hands and fingers, usually bringing the resolution down to 1-2mm so that the fingers have somewhere to start their materialization.
Does that help?

Enjoy!

comments.text: Trying to print Groot on the Snapmaker, hopefully the supports will go fine in this first attempt ! Will inform you after the print :)

It says that it is edited to print with no Raft, not no support, if that is where the confusion may be. I edited the bottom of the feet so that it would print on the glass directly, and stand on its own. The actual work was in determining through multiple prints what angle would be the best for the feet to be flattened at, and then cleaning up some Boolean cut errors. When printed right on the glass or tape (and use Hairspray!) the model now stands perfectly afterward.

description.text:
This is the result of a little processing sketch i wrote. It takes any
bitmap heightfields like the one in the images and turns it into a stl file
that can be printed on a makerbot http://www.local-guru.net/blog/2010/03/28/generating-3d-objects-from-heightfields

download and run the processing sketch from my blog post,
scale and rotate the stl object in blender
let blender remove the doublicate vertices to simplify the mesh
slice it using skeinforge
and print it on your 3D-Printer

Dial front A and 3mm square graver clamp 8th Feb 2017

Front Dial and Graver Clamp. Both prints came out well and I'm pleased that the lines for the 5 degree increments also printed nicely. The threaded brass inserts and 20mm M4 bolts fit well on these parts and it holds the tool steel securely,

One issue is that if the holding screw on the graver clamp is over tightened it can split plastic. I've edited the model now to have thicker walls at this place.

Frame B 13th Feb 2017

First part of the frame printed well (tho my print lifted from the bed slightly), this part fits together well with the dial front and the 30mm M4 bolts and threaded inserts.

Tightening the screw holds the dial in the desired position.

Dial Back B 15th February 2017 Finished Prints 3rd March 2017

The first part of my frame came put bowed so i want to reprint at some point, but the design works. I have an old dermal drill stand which I'm using as a base, its post is 16 mm in diameter but I'll upload the 123d design file so any one can edit this part to suit there own needs. I've created 2 gravers using this so far but clamping it to my drill press and using diamond lapidary discs on an arbor.

I've designed this to use M4 Bolts and 8mm x 5,8mm Embedded Nuts.

title: ANET A8 | Bowden Motor Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just did a minor modification to the original (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039986) motor mount for bowden extruders on the ANET A8 by Bakchos (all credit for the nice design goes to him).

The modification removes one edge slightly in order to work along with the tool holders: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1539675.
(Before it was not possible to remove the wrench anymore)

motor_block_alternative.stl is a replacement of the stock metal part of the extruder motor, which now allows to mount a M10 pneumatic push fitting. This fantastic thing is provided by Mafiatorte's design.

Suggestions:
1) This mount works well together with my bowden E3Dv6 hotend mount for the ANET A8: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577

2) If you don't like the stock extruder mechanism (so did I after some time), consider switching to this bowden extruder with non-stock drive gears!

description.text:
This night lamp was designed and build as a new year present. The idea came from a fancy globe night lamps with a wake up function and quickly got out of control.
The design was done in blender and tinkercad. It is 3d printed with a zortrax m200 printer. For the electronics it contains a teensy LC, a steel button as a capacitif touch button and an infrared remote.

A video of the light at work: https://youtu.be/c7YyH6Le0BA

In the video you can see the different functions, out the frame I'm pushing the buttons on the remote.
It has 3 basic functions:

  • one color mode
  • two color mode, the text has a different color
  • special programs (hue color loop, color random, dual color circle, ...)

The bottom is higher then necessary (about 2mm) I dremel the top part width an angle of 45 degree and did the same width the bottom part so that they fit very nicely, Do it in small steps for the best results. I did already printed the top before I thought of that, maybe someone wants to rework the parts.

The design and the code are opensource so you can build it yourself.

The code and build instructions:
https://github.com/brettdaman/ledstrip-night-lamp

author: iand64

description.text:
NEW Complete Aircraft https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2337232

I have uploaded the aircraft fuselage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2145201

Complete Clark-y airfoil wing for simple high wing trainer
Eventually this will be the wing for an 1133mm span (1050mm + 80mm center + 3mm for tips) 200mm chord + 35mm ailerons, "ugly" stick that will be mostly 3d printed, the fuselage is designed and after some test prints I will post it as well. This is the follow up to the first revision at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2022750
Servo mounts and control horns have been added, center section internal structure has been completely re-done.

This wing prints differently than most others I have seen, in slic3r I set it to print at 100% infill, one perimeter, no top or bottom layers & no supports. These settings seem to work well with a .35mm tip on my prusa I3 with PLA.
I have NOT printed the complete wing as of yet, only tests.
I have uploaded my original 123d design files and a complete set of .stl files. For design information and a small test section please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1994231

Printing instructions for the wing tips, ailerons and servo mounts :
Wing tips are printer flat
Ailerons print with either 2 or 3 perimeters & 20 - 30% honeycomb infill
Servo mounts printed @ 100% infill (designed to fit Tower Pro MG90S servos)

Aileron hinge pins are 2mm x 20mm long music wire or carbon fiber, use CA glue to attach aileron segments together
Leading and trailing edge joiner pins 3mm or 1/8th x 20mm long music wire or carbon fiber
Center spar, 10mm Carbon fiber or wood dowel, it should be 480mm to 550mm long or longer, it needs to go at minimum through the center and 2 inner panels, and 25mm into left & right center panels
Outer wing joiner (spar location) 10 mm x 25 to 50mm long
Wing panels are joined with CA glue
The servo wire joiner tubes are just CA glued to one side (center section or inner wing panel)

Note: the spar and joiner pin holes may need to be drilled or filed out slightly depending onn your printer.

Software used for this design, 123d Design & Inkscape.

comments.text:
New version coming soon!!!!
The new version is lighter, stronger and prints much easier and faster.
comments.author: tfrancis

comments.text: What software did you use to design this model?  Did you create all of the circle cut-outs in the wing's ribs manually?  Or is there some tool that can automatically "lighten" a thin surface quickly?
comments.author: Randino

comments.text:
I drew the aifoil with with Inkscape, everything else was done with 123d Design. The cutouts were simply done by creating a template of the airfoil & laying out the holes as required then using that to extrude through the ribs creating holes rather than solids.
The ribs themselves were laid out as curves in a box in 2d then I created using a simple copy and paste, pasting with a small offset. Then the ribs could be extruded giving me my rib layout without the airfoil. Then I used the airfoil template to cut the ribs and create the skin.
The other internal structures were all added after.
comments.author: Randino

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Y Belt Holder and Tensioner v5

description.text:
UPDATE 4/21/2017 - Redesign! It now uses the same small 2mm x 9mm wood screws, M3 screw and M3 nut that came with the Prusa i3 Kit but this time it all goes on a rear plate, easier to install and remove and stronger hold. After a few months if use I noticed my previous design would start to bend a bit due to its design, that won't happen with this design. I printed it with custom supports only on the rear section as you see in the photos. At 75% infill, printed them flat as you also see in the photos. Use a few extra top and bottom layers so that the screw holes are nice and solid. The square nut I just pressed into the hole on the plate.

UPDATE 3/17/2017 - Made it so that it uses 4 screws instead of 2, this will make sure that during tightening of the belt and prolonged use in a warm environment it doesn't lose it's shape and holds strong.

UPDATE 2/14/2017 - Adjusted the size of the pulley space and it is now exactly the width of the stock MK2 pulley. Fits really nice, there was a bit more space than I liked in the previous version. Enjoy!

This is a Y belt idler and tensioner for the Prusa i3 MK2 and MK1 as well. I am sure it works for other printers as well.

You will need one M3 screw and an one M3 square nut (spares came with the Orig. i3 Kit). You will also need two M2 x 8mm wood type screws to secure the bottom cover in place.

The nut goes into the side of the tensioner and the screw goes in through the back side. Once you install this idler/tensioner removing it is easy no need to remove the threaded rods! You just remove the belt pulley, flip over the tensioner and remove the 2 screws ho,ding the cover in place.

Printer:

Orig. Prusa i3 MK2

No

Yes

75%

title: Larson Class Destroyer (My Take)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my take on the old Fasa Larson class destroyer. I was watching a few Trekyards videos(Those guys are great) while working on some of the previous ships. There was one video about the Rules of Starship Design according to Gene Roddenbury. One of the rules was that there had to be an even number of nacelles to create a warp bubble. So, it got me thinking about how some of the ships Fasa made would have looked if they'd followed those rules. One of my favorite designs was the Larson, so I picked it as a starting point.

I wanted to keep the majority of the design, but also wanted the twin nacelles. From there, it didn't make sense how they'd route the warp conduits, so I added a tiny engineering section between the "wings". That way the warp conduits can just go straight to the nacelles and I could put the deflector dish on that.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 X Idler/Belt Tensioner+ v2

description.text:
UPDATE 3/17/2017 - I have updated both carriers the x tensioner and the x motor carrier to eliminate any binding on the x axis when using IGUS bearings mainly by correcting the spacing of the x rods on the carriers. I have included both upgraded carriers now the tensioner and the x motor carrier for the Original Prusa i3 MK2.

This is a X Idler/Belt Tentioner for the Original Prusa MK2 Printer. With this setup you can easily remove the x smooth rods of you need to without having to take apart your printer. Remove the tensioner screw and brace and slide out the rods. The x tensioner has built in manual supports that you will remove after printing.

You will need two M3 screws for the brace which out the pressure on the rods and not bend anything when tension is applied and an M4 and hex head bolt and nut. The bolt needs to be about 40mm and you can cut it to your size if need be if it's too long. The hex head screw goes into the pulley arm and through the idler and secure with the tensioner round screw that will have the nut placed inside of it in the space provided.

Printer:

Orig. Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

30%

Hey guys! You will probably need to print the translucent part (lum3.stl) with 99.5% just to have enough space to fit in the up and bottom parts otherwise the parts will need some sanding job!

Update 2017-03-02: lum3_v2.stl -> updated translucent piece with 0.15mm offset on both sides for a better fit.

Code used:

#include <Adafruit_NeoPixel.h>

#define PIN 3

const int tiltSensorPin = 2;
int seedR = 255, seedG = 242, seedB = 40, tiltSensorState = 1, originalTiltSensorState;
Adafruit_NeoPixel strip = Adafruit_NeoPixel(8, PIN, NEO_GRB + NEO_KHZ800);

void setup() {
pinMode(tiltSensorPin,INPUT);
strip.begin();
strip.show();
}

void loop() {
tiltSensorState = digitalRead(tiltSensorPin);
if(tiltSensorState != originalTiltSensorState) {
seedR = random(255);
seedG = random(255);
seedB = random(255);
originalTiltSensorState = tiltSensorState;
delay(500);
} else {
for(int i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
strip.setPixelColor(i, seedR, seedG, seedB);
}
}
strip.setBrightness(255);
strip.show();
}

I will keep troubleshooting. I might change sensors and I have a different type of vibration sensor laying around.

description.text:
The 'aloalo' (pronounced 'ah-loo-ah-loo') is a sculpture style in Madagascar that is most often associated with funerary poles. They are similar to American Indian totem poles in that they are typically vertically oritented with various layers associated with legends, notable events, and symbolism.

I decided to practice learning new 3d-modeling software by designing my own 'generic' version that is typical of other aloalo, but not indicative of a particular narrative or person.

I'd love to know what you think!

title: Bookshelf T-Brace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple T brace to repair an aging particleboard bookshelf of ours that could pose as the leaning tower of pisa.

The boards on our shelf are 16.5 mm thick so I made the bracket with 18 mm spacing to accommodate slight shrinkage (ngen doesn't shrink much). For other plastics I would scale it up just a bit. The holes for each screw are 6 mm in diameter.

I included a technical drawing so if anyone wants to modify it to fit different board thicknesses they may have an easier time with it.

comments.text: This is exactly what I was looking for for the bookshelves in my wife's classroom. Thank you!!!

author: mtnkyle

title: New England Patriots Logo - Multi Layer print REMIXED

description.text:
Noticed that the when I went to print the original, the face couldn't be printed the correct color (Silver/Gray) if I did the base in white. Also, the star needed to have a deeper hole if it was to be printed in a multilayer single extruder setup.

Those were the only two adjustments I made to the STL when REMIXING it.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

I printed mine at 70% Height to save some time, so the values I used to separate the processes in Simplify3D will reflect that.

I printed this by using Simplify3D's start and stop at height features to create 4 different G-Code files that when combined together created the awesomeness you see before you.

The process:
To begin you use the cross section view tool in Simplify3D to find the Z height in the model where you want to split the model into separate processes. You'll want to try and make the "cuts" at the same spots where the layers would normally be slicing the model.

Each process should start or stop where the next color should start or stop. Then you adjust each start script so that the nozzle moves up to the correct height before doing anything else and make an individual print file for each process.

Remember to change your material settings in the files you make for the filaments you'll be using. I forgot to do this, but thankfully it was on the very first print and not one of the latter ones.

Change out your loaded material on the printer between each print file and then you'll have a wonderful looking print just like mine!

Starting G-Code:
G28
G1 Z25 F1800; lower build plate to avoid crashing into part

Ending G-Code (Pretty standard):
G28 X0 Y0
M104 S0
M140 S0
M106 S0
M84

My 4 files were made up of the sections of the model split as follows:
-∞ : 3.50mm
3.50mm : 5.58mm
5.58mm : 7.00mm
7.00mm : ∞
